children.subject: Im also worried though my situation is different. My roommate and I were supposed to move in with our friend but that friend actually let go of his lease since he was worried fall might be remote. So we don't have any housing plan and can't apply for on-campus housing since it's too late (and we're 3rd years so we probably wouldn't get it anyway). Now I'm unsure whether to wait until the situation is more clear or to just take up a lease and start paying for it... Kind of worried we won't find housing if fall commences as normal
Really? Beaker, may i ask where? I want to tell my roomate and give him an example of somewhere that a late applicant got. You're a lifesaver tbh

Idk how but I got extremely lucky and got my first choice, a Channing Bowditch single (after getting terrible offers my last two years). I would recommend emailing the housing department to confirm though because I applied a few weeks ago!
Oh nice, yeah that's a good set up. I applied in any case, I might as well since I don't have a plan until anything is confirmed about fall. thanks!

Don't do co-op housing. They are charging residents a fee to cancel your contract in addition to paying the rent until the spot gets filled up.. and if things continue as is, chances are the spot won't get filled up so you pay the entire rent and the cancellation fee.

are you sure @anon gear? the co-op office told me "The deadline to cancel a Fall 2020 contract without penalty is July 8, so you will have another few months to see how things pan out. We encourage you to sign your contract now to secure your spot. If you cancel before July 8, you will have no financial penalties and will be able to get a refund of your security deposit and any rent you have paid."
I'm taking an on-campus apartment (u can still apply @anon mouse I am a junior and I applied late and already got an offer) bc they'll probably be the most lenient if class become remote

That's what I'm thinking as well. I think it's safe to wait until the end of this semester at the very least and I'd hope that they confirm whether fall will be remote or in-person by ~1.5/2 months out..
I'm still waiting for the school to make announcements about fall, probably won't do anything about housing yet until then.
Just signed a lease with some roommates, hope we do not just loose all that money if classes are online fa20

On-campus housing is really expensive, but otherwise seems like the best option, because they are the most likely to be lenient.

What I'm likely going to do is just wait it out. My guess is landlords are having trouble getting people to sign, so they'll become more and more lenient with their leases until people start signing them. Maybe some will even include a "coronavirus" clause in their lease should classes get cancelled again.

history.content:
Me and my roommates are currently thinking about fall housing and we were wondering about what others are planning to do. I think it's safe to say that no one knows how exactly the covid19 situation will develop over the summer and I haven't heard any official responses ruling out the possibility of fall being made remote. This is sort of problematic because we had already signed a lease this time last year. I'm just worried about the possibility of fall being made remote and then having to pay an expensive early termination fee. We're currently paying rent for an apartment that no one is living in due to everyone moving back home, so I don't think this worry is undue.

Just curious about your thoughts and plans. Sorry if this isn't totally relevant for this piazza, but wasn't sure what other forums to post this in to get legitimate advice!
history.subject: Curious about people's fall housing plans??
